Comment: No big surprise here. The city goes to the province for money. They say no, but you can raise it yourself through taxes. So the city comes back with the tolls on provincial highways whose upkeep was downloaded onto them. This way the people who use the road the most pay for its upkeep, regardless of where you live. Seems fair. TTC riders have to pay to  use the system each time. So the province initially is all in favor of this, but for political reasons only (sound familiar... gas plants and other huge wastes of money from this government?), change their mind. Or in political terms... flip flop. This is the same government that told us consumers to save on our hydro bills, we should use the system in off-peak hours. Then, when too many people do and they lose money, they charge extra to make up for the shortfall. Anyone who believes that Kathleen Wynne actually cares about this province and not doing whatever she can politically or otherwise to cling to power, needs to read more news.

Comment: A couple of observations based on 20 years of dipnetting off the beach: if there are fish coming into the river, you will catch them. Yep, you might get skunked once in a while, you might have a slow day, but that's just your bad timing. If you persist, you will get your fish.  I honestly can't correlate commercial activity with dipnetting success on any given day over the many days I have fished off the beach. 
     The Kenai River is not a damn supermarket. Better buy your fish from a broker or one of the food webs. The entitled attitude of many Anchorage fisherman would be laughable if it weren't so annoying.  We support our commercial fishermen and the biologists that do their best to guess what is going on with the run.

Comment: I guess I'm a 34-year marginal outsider who is not a knowledgeable Alaskan and must, therefore, be left behind in understanding Mr. Havelock's profound and irrefutable evidence.  Unfortunately, even the democrat commenters who beat me here see more than Mr. Havelock does.

Let's see, the Governor's (and Mr. Havelock's and Mr. Dunbar's) crisis does not exist.  Last year's $4-6 Billion budget was funded through savings.  In 2015 it appeared that we had combined CBR and Earnings Reserve savings of $12 Billion.  It appears that about $2 Billion was deposited into the Earnings Reserve from the Permanent Fund corpus, and we still have about $12 Billion in savings in 2016-17.  So effective reductions are still available to us.  Let's start with a 3-year freeze on merit increases, and a limit to the number of $500,000+ helpers the Governor can hire.

If, indeed, someone decides we need a tax, as Mr. Havelock thinks we do, put a 3 year sunset on that too. Not enough space allowed to go on.

Comment: It shouldn't be a matter of "want".  Felis catus is a highly-destructive invasive species.  It's also a vector of over three-dozen zoonotic diseases.  It's illegal to release them into the wild.

Yes, this mess is due to ill-considered human behavior--particularly worthless "no-kill" programs.  I simply can't take seriously anyone so inept and lazy they can't make a 12 lb. domesticated animal stay in the house.  Such an individual isn't competent to have pets, and should take pity on their pet and euthanize it.

For 12 of the last 13 years my wife and I kept two indoor-only cats.  The oldest, a female, died in May at age 18.  The youngest, a male rescued as a tiny kitten in Sand Pt. in November 2004, succumbed to cancer in October of last year at age 12.  Prior to that they did just fine wrestling with each other and--the male at least--stalking, killing and eating the invasive European hobo spiders which got in the house.

Comment: "who do you think should do the killing?"

Anyone and everyone. This is a community problem, so everyone who wants to be part of the solution should be allowed to help. As I said above: remove all protections on free ranging cats, and allow people to help. People who allow their pets to roam outside are part of the problem, because their pets are part of the problem. It would be very sad if pets were killed, but ultimately it is the owner's responsibility to make sure their pets are not out killing birds.

Years ago some Vermont acquaintances got one warning from the Ranger: Next time I see your dog running deer, I'll shoot it. Next time she saw it running deer, she did. 

Vermont does not pretend that trapping, neutering, and releasing dogs solves any problems. They are serious about threats. We just want to feel good about ourselves. If we were serious about feral cats, we would kill them. Neutered cats eat birds. Don't release them. Kill them.

Comment: I also question whether you actually know anything about the cost of purchasing and maintaining a rental property.

An average home in Portland is currently $371k, but let's say $350k for an easy round number, 2 bd/1ba bungalow (good luck trying to find one in a close-in neighborhood at that price though)

$70k down. + $10-30k in renovations, depending on condition.
$1,350/mo mortgage.
$4k/yr property tax (and rising every year), so $333/mo.
$1k/yr homeowners insurance, so $83/mo.
$2k/yr average maintenance, so $167/mo.

We're at $$1,933/mo. now, for a 2 bd/1ba bungalow, and that's after the $70-100k initial investment that is now a non-liquid equity asset that is subject to the risks in my prior comment.

A quick Craigslist search shows that 2bd/1ba houses like this rent from $1500 - $2100/mo.

Tenant doesn't pay, eviction and loss of security deposit. Landlord doesn't pay, foreclosure and loss of $70-$100k.

You teach math, correct? Is this a "greedy killing" for this landlord?

Comment: You can hunt moose with a permit and small game by archery, .22 rifle, shotgun, and falconry in the Skilak Loop Management Area. You can hunt moose, black bears, brown bears, Dall sheep, mountain goats, and small game in Chugach State Park.  Got any others?

The full-curl restrictions on Dall sheep hunting and antler restrictions for moose hunting are not intended to allocate animals among user groups.  They are to keep hunters from shooting too many sheep and moose while avoiding restrictions on the number of hunters (by permits) or extremely short hunting seasons.

Comment: "Once a bastion of social democracy,......"

Anyone familiar with political theory and European politics would know that France has never been considered a social democratic state.  Like Germany or Austria, France is typified as 'conservative-corporatist' (conservative in the traditional sense of the word).  A heavy reliance on social insurance approach to programs (very different from universalist approaches of social democratic states), and a desire to maintain the historical social hierarchy (which explains why France has one of the lowest rates of economic mobility among Western industrialized countries).  

Easy to understand in that the Presidency and Parliament has typically been held by parties of the Gaulist orientation and right wing governments. Mitterrand, a social democratic leader, did hold the presidency for much of the 1980s, but swung hard right by his second term. But add up all the years and it is Gaulist/right wing that occupy the most space of governance in France

Comment: When I started teaching there was a class next door with learning disabled young children. They were given training and I recall letter formation and reversals were remediated.  There was a couple of classes in the system.  Within five years, those classes were replaced and more specific visual and auditory learning disabilities (memory & discrimination).  One previous poster mentioned that dyslexia is just one category that is language based.  I agree.  Dyslexia term has not been used in diagnosis or treatment in school systems for a reason.  WISC is the testing application to get an idea about the learning disabilities by someone trained in the testing using WISC ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wechsler_Intelligence_Scale_for_Children).  It was often given before the more expensive/intensive testing over several days by pyschomotrist.  Testing and application have improved over the 1960's misuse of the word Dislexia.

Comment: He's guilty. Here's why: First, he's a concealed-carry guy. That puts him in league with a bunch of nut cases. However, this alone is not enough. Second, he's feeding squirrels on a full-time basis (a no-no). Third, he's feeding them peanuts, which is an allergen to children in his neighborhood. Fourth, his neighbors don't want him to do it, but he persists, nevertheless. Fifth, he's doing it to commune with the dead (cuckoo!). Fifth, he places flyers everywhere to explain his craziness. Sixth, he shot an unarmed man. Seventh, he shot him in the back. Eighth he sustained no injuries.

No single fact is enough to convict him. Facts six through eight are the most damning. If you want to be authorized to carry a firearm, you must be highly accountable for the actions taken with it. Any hint of impropriety should be viewed through a lens that assumes you acted as such. The burden should then be on you to rebut the presumption, and it should be a heavy burden.

Comment: It took 2 months to wipe out 12 months of equity, this is correct. 
What you describe as tail end of panic is called a "bull trap" research it. 
DEFINITION of 'Bull Trap'
A false signal indicating that a declining trend has reversed and is heading upwards when, in fact, the security will continue to decline.
 http://www.investopedia.com/terms/b/bulltrap.asp#ixzz4nHAgSNns 

It's not only the interest that matters it's also the lose of liquidity in the market. 
Home Capital and all their peers are no longer lending just renewing. 
The worst part about a home purchase today is that even if you put down 20% the bank may only value the home you bought at 85% of what you paid and loan you 80% of that amount. On 1M dollars that means they will only lend you 
$680,000 because they know equity is dropping and they need a "margin of safety".  
The fact also remains: no investor will pay 10% transaction cost(5% on purchase 5% on sale) for an asset with a negative cash flow which is losing value.

Comment: As a very new teacher I had a (girl) learner giving me a hard time in class.  Sarah was a buxom lass, just as tall as I.  I didn't realise it at the time, but my right hand was twitching - wanting to strike her.  
She noticed it.  She looked at me levelly and said: "Strike me, Ma'am, and you have lost your job!"   
That broke the tension and we both just let it go.
However, I went home and reflected on it for a long time.  I had been trained never to hit a learner, but I now realised that - somewhere in the back of my mind - I did think that I could hit someone - as a 'last resort'.   I was shocked at me, and I had to accept that shame before I could move forward.  
That long afternoon and evening (and many times since) I had to think of strategies which I could use to get the 'Sarahs' of this world to do what I wanted them to do - and be happy about it!   
This was one of the best confrontations that I ever had. Forty years later, I am grateful to Sarah.

Comment: Absolutely true, what most don't seem to grasp is that at least one generator is essentially running 24/7 at any given time in any given community (regardless of wind).  Small loads such as light bulbs don't mean much in these small rural utilities unlike those on the grid.  The thing that makes a real difference is if the largest loads in a village can be reduced, which are typically the appliances at the residential level and the washeteria / schools / fish plants at the commercial.  And that is where capturing the waste heat (mechanical energy or kWM) can really displace energy costs if it's redirected to a boiler via a heat loop.

Comment: Trid...it doesn't matter if they're Catholic. The theological disposition of NT scholars doesn't (or rather, shouldn't) factor in to analysis of the texts. Whether Paul authored a letter may be determined by scrutiny of syntax and other stylistic features, vocabulary, historical clues within the text, theological disposition, and other data intrinsic to the texts, as well as external, corroborative evidence. The scholarly consensus on the Pauline epistles is so accepted that John P. Meier, the Catholic favorite of historical Jesus scholars, refers in "A Marginal Jew" to the "authentic and pseudonymous" Pauline Epistles.

That's not to say there's agreement on the pseudepigraphic (non-authentic) letters. They're still DISPUTED. The consensus lies in acceptance of seven of the epistles as authentic. They are, in chronological order:

1 Thessalonians
Galatians
1 Corinthians
2 Corinthians
Philemon
Philippians
Romans

Comment: Aktionaer

I too self direct my investments (mostly). 

I hold 23 individual equities, 1 (gulp) mutual fund and a small basket of ETFs in a work RRSP which I have for the employer match contributions. 

This is a breakdown of the fees I paid last year. It will show you the clear cost savings of self directed investments in individual equities. 

Individual equities 93.6% of the portfolio, 18.7% of total fees paid last year, Expense Ratio 0.019%. 

Mutual Fund 4.3% of the portfolio, 53.7% of total fees paid last year, Expense Ratio 1.18%

ETFs 2.1% of the portfolio, 27.6% of total fees paid last year, Expense Ratio 1.26%

To put it another way, the ETFs are 2.1% of my portfolio and the fees on them exceeded the fees on the individual equities which were 93.6% of the portfolio. (As did the fees on the MF @ 4.3% of the portfolio)

Expense ratio on the total portfolio was 0.095%

Comment: [It's the contract we made to sell our mutual resources]
You're conflating two separate and distinct areas of law.  Contract law is, for the most part, common law.  Common law is a very different thing from statutes.  For example, common law is customary judge made law while statutes are legislative acts.
Contract law is also somewhat distinct from Trust law.  Trust law is a better position to argue from in regards to the PFD because contract law requires three elements at the core of any case.  An offer, acceptance and consideration while a trust can be inferred.
FYI - Consideration is a legal term, different from the common usage in the English language.
Regardless, contract law really doesn't apply in regards to the PFD.  It was never offered to the Alaskan public.  It was created by Constitutional and legislative process.  Per above, statutes are not contracts in the legal sense, e.g. if a contract conflict with a valid statute (for example violating labor laws) the statute wins.

Comment: "In every major war since Korea, more of our veterans have taken their lives than have lost them in combat. The latest research, rooted in veteran testimony, reveals that the most severe and intractable PTSD -- fraught with shame, despair, and suicide -- stems from ''moral injury.'' But how can there be rampant moral injury in what our military, our government, our churches, and most everyone else call just wars? At the root of our incomprehension lies just war theory -- developed, expanded, and updated across the centuries to accommodate the evolution of warfare, its weaponry, its scale, and its victims. Any serious critique of war, as well any true attempt to understand the profound, invisible wounds it inflicts, will be undermined from the outset by the unthinking and all-but-universal acceptance of just war doctrine. " WorCat summary of
Shay's "Killing from the Inside Out". Shay was chosen by VA vets to be their voice. Let this be a companion read to the series. A then and Now...

Comment: Frank, by your logic reducing Denali National Park wolves by snaring and killing them at bait stations ten feet from the park boundary is good for tourism.   Not true.  People coming to Denali Park especially want to see bears, wolves- and Mt. McKinely. (Now Denali).

Visitors now have about a 4% chance of seeing a wolf- compared to about 50% when the buffer was in place.  

The entire East Fork pack has been exterminated by bait stations/snaring.  Visitors now have  ZERO percent chance of seeing an East Fork wolf.

The entire Denali Park population is now less than 50 wolves.  

What you are not seeing is how many additional park visitors that would come to Alaksa to see these wolves- the percentage of increase lost. (How do you measure the tourists we lose?)  Tourists are now more likely to spend their money in Yellowstone if they want to see wolves.

Comment: Does Carl Rodrigues hand over the rights of software patents to Canadian software developers who invent them?  Of course he does not. These companies can do with it what they like, for example move operations to San Francisco or sell the IP to global provider of software or services. 

There are clear benefits for Canada when companies develop here but please don't mislead the readers.  

Try going through the interview process for Software Engineering jobs. The expectations are often ludicrous. They expect your past experience to identically match their needs and have no concept that an experienced engineer can learn the specifics of a domain once employed in it. Try investing in training and development of skills instead of whining about losing talent to others.

Comment: The only well established case where small pox infested blankets were distributed to native Americans  was during Pontiac's rebellion when they were besieging the British and American colonists at Fort Pitt (Pittsburgh). What effect that might have  had  on the more general small pox epidemic at the time affecting native Americans and settlers  at the time is moot. (You might want to read about Pontiac's rebellion. The brutality was rather two-way.)  There aren't, so far as I know, instances of the Hudson's Bay Company or the Northwest Company or their agents in Canada distributing small pox infested blankets. The reason is that fur trading companies depended on aboriginal suppliers for their furs and much else for survival. Killing off your suppliers would be a self-destructive way of doing business.  That isn't to say that small pox wasn't a scourge among Canadian aboriginals but its spread was through human contact.

Comment: There is a slight problem with your proposed "solution".  It is contrary to our supreme law of the land. 

The claim of  persecution will be against the claimants home country and not the US unless they had lawful or protected status accorded then in the US and thus far none have been reported to have such status.

Under the 1985 Singh decision "everyone" IN Canada is entitled to s.7 Charter protection - "fundamental justice" (our version of due process) means an oral hearing on the merits of the claim before an independent administrative tribunal.

The federal government exploited a technical loophole in the Singh decision that a person who comes to a Port of Entry from the USA is not technically IN Canada and so can be referred back.

Being in a third country or multiple third countries whether "safe" or not does not make one ineligible to make a claim to refugee status in Canada per our international obligations and as set out in the case law from the Federal Court of Canada.

Comment: I think I agree in general, Bob; provided you leave room for mysticism. 

Mysticism involves some measure of conscious awareness of the action of Spirit, which of course in not constant. Since this consciousness is not constant, than there it begins and ends (fads in out). Further, I think we have to distinguish (1) Classical mysticism (the experience of the great mystics) from (2) Mysticism Light (a common experience which is open to all. The difference between the two, is in Classical mysticism, the mystic can not deny and has no doubt about the experience, but with Mysticism Light, discernment is ALWAYS required. That is, under spiritual direction, one must attempt distinguish the activity of (1) the Good Spirit, and (2) the bad spirits, and (3) my own spirit (my own personality, with all of its neuroses and capacity for self-delusion. 

So long as you are not insisting on the continuous action of the Spirit as the first step in denying mystic experience, I agree.

Comment: True-- happens all the time. Weather forecasters issued warnings to evacuate well in advance, but the Mayor of Houston never even suggested a voluntary evacuation-- instead he recommended people stay at home. Houston had no plan for an evacuation and no plan to rescue people who stayed at home. In a few hours it was too late to evacuate as forecasts proved accurate and many needed rescue. Just as in the case of New Orleans, engineers warned of the risk, but reckless development and lack of planning and action led to disaster-- in Houston it was destruction of wetlands. The national flood insurance act was supposed to force people to pay the costs of flood control or move out. But the law was weakened. People were skeptical-- they had three 500 year floods in three years but still never recognized the risk and the rising of flood risks and severity of storms in the region.

Comment: It is time for the business community to start moving their system to Linux and put pressure on developers to write good apps for the platform. Obviously there is no perfect secure system, but Linux has a robust and tight architecture, which makes it much less venerable to attacks and viruses.  Even when compromised the damage can be contained within the environment. 

I also understand that Linux has reduced number of attacks, because there are less hackers writing malware to affect the platform. But even if hackers  decide to  target it they would face more challenges than writing apps for Windows and its weaker architecture, which includes the vulnerable Registry.

Users also  need to stop being silly. Case in point:  I'm waiting for a package from Canada Post and I got an official  "Ship Notification for Item". A few hours later I got another email from "Canada Post", which was clearly suspicious. Then I thought how many people would have clicked the link and got in trouble.

Tampering is illegal.  Influencing is not. 
Do you understand the issue now?

Comment: Gone are the days when one could leave High School and get a secure job for 35 years, with a pension that allowed one to enjoy the toys of life in retirement. I think many of our politicians, and think-tank directors see this, but reality is that we have about 40% of the population that grew up with this thinking. It's not easy to change, but some must, because they are facing dramatic workplace changes for which they are unprepared. 

However, I believe our primary focus needs to be on equipping the young to cope with multiple career changes and adapting to the new technology. Which means new skills for educators, and a new revolving door structure for the education system so people can return and augment their skills at a later date. Secondarily we need to help current workers transition to new jobs, or retirement, successfully.

Comment: Is it too much to mention that there is virtually nothing Christian about Christmas?

Keep in mind that this was an old "pagan" holiday to celebrate the winter solstice.  There's a reason why you won't ever find any mention of decorating evergreen trees anywhere in the bible.  This, and most other things we do around Christmas time, have absolutely nothing to do with Christianity.

The injection of Christianity into the winter solstice celebrations has a variety of historical roots, but was mostly done for the sake of convenience.  Christians wanted some day to celebrate the birth of Christ so why not lump in with a day that was already being widely celebrated, hence the selected the (northern hemisphere) winter solstice in the Roman calendar, December 25th.

So what do we celebrate?  Well mostly a mix of pagan traditions combined with modern consumerism and the celebration of a figure who's modern likeness was popularized by a soft drink company.

Christian?  Not so much.

Comment: To help assuage fears why not use the same computer technology that counts the votes to verify the vote tabulated by machine?   Why can't the state produce two-part serialized "verification" ballots to be provided to voters who want to use them.  The voter would have a copy of the ballot counted by the machine. The State could issue these ballots at the polling place (or by mail) in lieu of a regular ballot.  There would be no record of who received these ballots. These "verification" ballots will create a database that  the suspicious voter could then check at home (or other location) by looking up that serial number and see if  the machine count matches the ballot as marked. If the voter is upset after checking, let him or her request (and pay for) a certified copy of the ballot for comparison to use to support a challenge. The voter copy would need to exactly match the original or the challenge would be very suspect.

Comment: The 1982 North Anchorage Land Agreement settled what was left to sort out from ANCSA.  Between the State, the Federal Government, the Alaska Railroad and privately held land there was not enough public land contiguous to the traditional lands of Eklutna for their entitlement.  As a part of the deal Eklutna was granted half of the revenue from remaining public lands in the area.  They don't get ownership of the land, but they do get some future benefit.

Under the agreement, they have a pretty good claim at half of the revenue from the methane sold at the dump.  Also included in this deal, Eklutna gives up its claim on a place the city wants to build a new power substation, and gives up a gravel quarry.

Meanwhile, the city gets two new subdivisions to tax (Powder Acres and Powder Hills), and retains all future methane sales.  It's a pretty good deal for the city.

Collier is eligible to receive 100% of the bonus amount if he is terminated with or without good cause, so long as there is a positive final record of decision with 12 months following the date of his termination. Comment: Hey, guess what?  Anyone can play this game, even the Greens and NDP.  All they have to do is win the most riding elections by getting the most votes in each.  Just because two main parties are currently successfully occupying the centre right and centre left, where a clear majority of voters reside, doesn't make our system wrong.  

What I think is wrong with our system is that MPs do not have enough power to influence votes in the House to best represent their constituents.  I still think that, with the exception of confidence votes,  all party whipped votes should be eliminated.  This would force a majority of  votes to be free votes, essentially approached as they would under a minority government.  Party leadership must convince, not mandate their MPs, to vote a certain way.  The power is returned to MPs and their constituents, away from the PMO.

Comment: That there were criminal gangs in the past is indisputable, but I think BP's point is sound in some respects, it was *for mainstream society*, i.e. MOST people, a less anxious, violent, conflict-ridden society. (Not because of RC faith, but for a variety of reasons.)  New York was well known for its violence, ethnic and other, as was L.A., yet the violence depicted in West Side Story for example was mild compared to what happens today, even in  Canada. It was big news in school if someone got into a fistfight, no one could have imagined using knives and guns and razor blades, etc.

Which is not to say it was better for everyone, in every respect. There are always marginal groups in every society, and being on the criminal margins was no fun, but for mainstream, middle class society, i.e. MOST people, it was safe, I don't see how anyone can dispute that. 

But we still are one of the safest cities in the world, and would like to keep it that way.

Comment: "...shut it down and die."

Most Catholics don't even know what the Curia is, much less know who is in that institution or group; but you want it dismantled. Maybe replace it with global representatives from the 150 or so National Conferences of Bishops representing 1.2 billion Catholics? I don't know. I haven't the answer except that it will take a long time to dismantle the Curia -- to make the unrigging successful. Bishops can do it by asserting themselves as individual national bodies, but that seems unlikely right now. Some National Conferences of Bishops, of course, are more progressive than others. In the meantime, in dealing with abuse in churches (and everywhere, really), the best route (for bringing about reform) seems to be through local civil courts, sympathetic laypeople and clerics, the press, and Pope Francis. If courts jailed a few bishops, that might help a lot, too.

Um, what they mean is it won't cost them anything YET.  Because the surcharges don't start until 2022.

If they're going to do this, then they should also be adding the cost of "idled" conventional power generation facilities to inconsistent/undependable sources (wind/solar).  That's a huge hidden cost of wind and solar that's rarely accounted for.  In other words, to use wind or solar, it's the cost of that source PLUS a portion of the cost of that natural gas plant that has to be there to back up wind/solar when the wind doesn't blow and the sun doesn't shine.

I doubt the Liberals are going to gain or lose much support on their tax changes, those are sufficiently complex that the vast bulk of Canadians eyes are likely to glaze over when reading about them.  Some will oppose the changes, some will support them, but few will change their vote based on those changes.

A bigger concern for the Liberals is some of the damning reports coming out about their lack of accountability.  The up-coming fighter jet purchase decisions will almost certainly hurt them badly too, no matter what choice they make, since they painted themselves into a 'no-win' situation during the 2015 election campaign.

The real kicker though will be what happens to the global economy over the next year or so.

Comment: The world will be a less happy place without Frank.
A loyal co-worker, union brother and friend. Frank was a brother I never had.  If you had a project, no matter how hard, Frank was there to help.  He was the guy who would mow the neighbor's lawn with no expectations of thanks.  Frank fits all the descriptions of real friends.  He was a people person and very social.
Frank was true to his ethnic heritage-Croatian.  Like most Aberdeen Croatians Frank had roots in the Nerevta Valley of Croatia, home to Matich, Bebich, Manenica, Celich, Vekich and Franich families all kinsmen. Frank liked to say we were just Serbs who had been lucky to escape the Turks- We would tease back Frank about being an "old country Croat without ever being to the old country... 
Frank loved his cars and like his Dad was handy.
Frank was loyal to his family and loved his sister Jean's
kids and their friends and spoke of them often.  They gave him joy.
He never stopped loving his son, Andrew. 
We will remember you.

Comment: "farming was going great guns in Greenland"

No, it wasn't. There were two marginal settlements in southern Greenland raising cattle, pigs, goats and sheep and hunting walrus, whales and polar bears. Experiments to grow barley failed, so all that was grown was winter silage for the animals. Eventually the cattle and pigs died off, and the goats and sheep dwindled. The Norse settlers slowly switched to a diet rich in seal and fish, dwindled in numbers themselves, and by the early 1400s had either returned to Iceland and Norway (both depopulated by plague) or died off.

Comment: Petronas cancelled due to the 'glut' of LNG -- look at all the facilities in Australia.  A global corporation like Petronas doesn't have to worry about silly details like national or provincial governments when it makes decisions.  This decision is in Petronas' best interest.  On July 24, 2014, the Financial Post reported Petronas was seeking potentially $-billions in tax relief from Ottawa ... in other words, subsidies for opening new markets for Canadian natural gas. The proposed LNG plant would cost $9 to $11-billion.  Petronas said it could not afford 7% B.C. tax on export profits AFTER recouping development costs. It wanted tax concessions including a 30% capital cost allowance.  The Canadian Assoc'n of Petroleum Producers agreed with such concessions, saying it allowed companies to write off 90% of their investments within 7 years. Can anyone imagine the fed'l or prov'l governments writing off their 'investments' (debts or deficits) within 7 years?? Too many subsidies!

Comment: While opinion articles are not bound by the normal rigors of journalistic fact checking, one would hope that a piece written by the Editorial Board would at least have its facts straight.
Tax revenue from recreational consumer sales do not pay for OLCC operation and regulation of the marijuana program. That is covered under the registration fees that are paid by everyone who owns a recreational marijuana business.
Furthermore the breakdown of the tax revenue is misleading. From the OLCC website the tax revenue is divided as follows:
40 % to Common School Fund, 
20 % to Mental Health Alcoholism and Drug Services, 
15 % to State Police, 
10 % to Cities for enforcement of the measure, 
10 % to Counties for enforcement of the measure, 
5 % to Oregon Health Authority for alcohol and drug abuse prevention. 
The taxes go to law enforcement and questionable drug prevention programs.  It's an issue that must be addressed in the legislature.

Comment: When you burn a hydrocarbon you end up with basically 4 things:

- Water
- Carbon dioxide
- Energy
- Pollution

The amount of the first two is pretty much fixed and generally the goal is to maximize energy (or at least usable energy) while minimizing pollution.

When discussing greenhouse gases or carbon emissions or anything like that though we're mostly talking about the second emission, and as noted above it is mostly fixed for a given quantity of a particular fuel.  If you burn 1 litre of gasoline you'll end up with 2.31kg of CO2.  If you burn X kg of a lignite coal you'll get Y kg of CO2, etc.

So, what does this mean for a person?  Well if it costs $50 to for 1000kg (1 tonne) of CO2 then the 2.31kg from burning 1 litre of gasoline is going to cost 11.55 cents.

How that cost gets passed on to you, the end consumer, depends on the implementation.  B.C. charges it directly, Ontario plans to bury it in the price.

As long as the two camps keep fighting — behind our backs — there will be no common sense in Math or anything else in education.  It's a contest between the Progressives and Traditionalists.

Progressives having concluded that a class system with disparities in income is unfair — work to achieve equality. Believe in collective and group work in school. 

Traditionalists see civilization as a steady evolution based on lessons from the past — work to build on knowledge and skills. The individual is the unit for education growth.

Comment: I find it totally bizarre, the Canadian media's usage, like a tool, of the American health care system.

Think about it. Here are ten foreign countries that have health care systems: Australia, New Zealand, England, France, Germany, Sweden, Japan, America, Norway and China.

Now think about this number: 98 percent.

That is, 98 percent of the coverage we read about, on foreign health care systems, is about America's. The coverage is 98 percent of the time talking about the United States.

Um, hello? What is the agenda here of the editors? Seriously, is it to toss out a patriotic bit of meat now and then so that we Canadians can say wow, we are doing so much better than the Americans?

Or is it to keep Canadians blind to approaches other health care systems overseas are using that in some areas might be better than ours?

Honestly, I do not understand the America-fixation on health care. It is reasonable to suspect an agenda: Editors do not blare a horn repeatedly for no reason...

Comment: I have lived in Magnolia over 10 years, and I am strongly in favor of Tent City 5 remaining where it is.

 I do agree with the previous poster that it would be better for everyone to have a roof over their heads. Magnolians can help move toward this goal by supporting the development of affordable housing at Fort Lawton. In the meantime, however, it is obvious that there is not enough affordable shelter in Seattle. Saying that people should not stay in tent encampments more than 180 days is not realistic, since there is nowhere else to go. The tent city provides a sense of community and stability that can help people find jobs and a support system. Can you imagine having to move every 90 days? Even worse, can you imagine not knowing each night where you would spend the night? The stress must be unthinkable.

As for Emerson St, I am a bike commuter and rode often through that encampment. I never felt unsafe. People were just minding their own business.

Comment: When you think about it, everything is funded by the public. Your salary and all your benefits are rolled up into the price of the goods or services, you or your company sell, regardless if you are a public or private entity. Every time we buy groceries, we the public, are paying for everybody's wages and benefits, from the clerk at the register, to the delivery truck driver and beyond. I worked for a PERS employer and I contributed 6% out of my monthly pay for 30 years. Yes my employer matched that and I am so grateful and lucky and I wish everybody could have the same. I have friends and family who work in the private sector (a doctor and an auto mechanic) and their employers match the % they put into their 401k. So when I go to that doctor or go get my car worked on, I'm funding my family and friends, wages and benefits. Everything is wrapped up in everything we buy, whether it's a product or a service.

Comment: Public transit agencies don't deserve to be funded by a proposed employee income tax, as the current transportation proposal includes.  TriMet and LTD are becoming huge money pits.  

TriMet has almost a $1 BILLION  unfunded liability in their retirement/benefits account, and LTD has a  $26 million in unfunded pension and OPEB liability as reported on their balance sheet.

Furthermore, since LTD begun their focus on EmX projects and proposals, they have been forced to cut almost 19% of their basic transit service, have lost about 10% ridership,  yet LTD has still added more staff to their bloated administration.  (Per the November 2015 “Performance Review”, and followed-up by a November 2016 “Technical Memorandum”, done by CSA Planning for the Eugene Chamber of Commerce.) 

LTD transit has become MORE costly, yet LESS efficient, and seemingly more about shelf preservation than providing sensible, affordable, and sustainable public transit.

Comment: I disagree with no shortage. there is a shortage of housing in Toronto. The city under political pressure to slow down construction has resulted in a shortage of housing. There are 15,000 condos completed each year (thats all the trades can build each year - supply constraint) and based on population growth via immigration , birth rates and migration the demand is 20,000 homes are needed to service demand. There are 100,000 new residents each year coming to the Toronto GTA. There is also the 80/20 principle as 80% of demand is for low rise but the supply is only 20%  so there is more demand for this type of housing that results in bidding wars. "In 21st-century English, buses is the preferred plural of the noun bus. Busses appears occasionally, and dictionaries list it as a secondary spelling, but it’s been out of favor for over a century. This is true in all main varieties of English.

After bus emerged in the 19th century as an abbreviation of omnibus, buses and busses (the logical plural of buss, an early alternative spelling of bus) vied for dominance for several decades. Comment: I agree that in the long run you will probably do better, financially, if you move to northern California. Despite the absurd cost of housing, you can do pretty well even on a junior software engineer's salary living in a one bedroom apartment. Many Google employees have contributed to an internal wiki page on how to live on the Google campus, rent free (they have free meals, showers, plenty of comfortable places to sleep, lockers to keep changes of clothes -- the big caveat is that you have no prospect of any kind of love life). Moreover, your career prospects are better because you can move more easily between companies and working in HQ has a lot of intangible advantages, like being better connected to decision-making.

There is more to it than money, though. If you have a spouse and/or kids, downgrading from a 2500 sqft house on a quarter acre lot to a 1400 sqft home while adding $600k to your mortgage is not an easy thing, despite the higher salary and the nicer weather.

Comment: As a Victoria resident, a reader, and a frequent patron of Munro's, I too mourn Jim Munro's loss. I didn't know him personally, but saw him at the store often, and attended authors' events he and his staff hosted in the city.

A book-loving city if ever there was one,  Victoria is temporarily at a loss of words because of the passing of one of its greatest champions of literature and culture.

The obituary here from Paul Willcocks is also most welcome, as Paul is a long-time journalist from Victoria, and a fitting eulogist for Jim Munro.

Comment: As a resident and regular patron of over ten years, I can honestly say that I have only had ONE bad experience; and that was years ago. 

I bring my kids, now eight and 13, to the library often, and we never have problems. Perhaps it's because we mind our own business and don't concern ourselves with what others are doing as long as it presents no threat of harm to us. We don't fear diversity, and we don't categorize people as threats simply because they *look* like they have less money or may be homeless. Honestly, we have NEVER witnessed criminal activity or felt afraid while visiting the library.

People need places to go, safe, public places where they can meet without the expectation of spending money. Maybe they're teenagers who just want to hang out with their friends (I remember being a teenager here. We weren't criminals, we were kids). Maybe they are homeless and need a warm place to be. If they aren't breaking any laws, they have just as much right to the space as anyone.

Comment: "Oh I get it! By prohibiting the expression of ones fundamental rights in public spaces, you believe we'll all get along."

That's one, not particularly honest, way of putting it.  Another is that official secularism insulates shared offices that should benefit every last citizen from being steered to solely or preferentially benefiting a specific constituency. It's no different than the policy of making certain parliamentary offices non-partisan, or making Prime Ministers put their personal investments into trust while they hold office, or why conflict of interest or lobbying policies exist for government officials.

We ALL benefit from officially neutral public services, whether we're believers or non-believers.  Official accommodation sought 'neutrality' by accommodating everyone, but true secularists knew that certain beliefs were always going to need more accommodation than others, and that this would lead to inevitable conflict ... and it has.

Comment: I'm not sure I agree that FERC should avoid playing any role with respect to having environmental attributes be considered by the market.

The nominees went on to say that FERC should not interfere with state environmental initiatives.  Should I take this to mean that they agree that FERC should not interfere with state policies that give small subsidies to existing nuclear plants (in order to properly credit them for their non-polluting nature)?  Also, that they agree that the current lawsuits against nuclear subsidies, which claim that they are illegal because the "interfere" with the interstate power market, are absurd and completely w/o merit?

We currently have a beyond absurd situation where very small interventions on nuclear's behalf are being legally challenged, whereas orders-of-magnitude-larger market interventions on renewables behalf (i.e., literal mandates for a large renewables share) are completely unopposed.  How can those mandates be OK?

Comment: That's a good broad point.   But the PF was created for the collective benefit of all future generations of Alaska.    The PFD was conceived as a means to distribute this collective benefit individually through payments.    An accrued interest is a right you acquire over time.   There is no "right" to a dividend that was created simply because it has been paid over a long period of time.     It's a gift, not an entitlement.   If the citizens of Alaska wanted to create a "right" to it, then you are correct, we could do so through an initiative.   But presently, it's a annual "gift" as allowed by law.

Comment: "Addressing the supply side is not only beneficial for housing affordability in the long term, but it adds these great things called jobs in the economy, and growth"

I don't like that Mr. Muir and others don't address the nature of existing demand. It's not like it's just demand for a place to live. It is speculative demand, facilitated in part by the ever-expanding record high levels of household debt. It is demand for a safe haven for foreign capital (coupled with citizenship/ residency of convenience). 

It's a crude assessment, but if you take the Lower Mainland's pop. growth numbers and the # of units being built, more than enough supply for shelter is being built.

Real estate has grown to >1/4 of BC's GDP, bigger than forestry, mining, and other sectors COMBINED. Completely ignoring knock-on effects (e.g. bleeding young talent that represents essential skills and the future tax base) while advocating further pumping of this single bloated sector is just nakedly self-serving.

Comment: The RCMP are applying the law as passed by Parliament.

The RCMP are arresting and detaining them under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and turning them over to Canada Immigration for processing.

There is a very good legal reason why refugee claimants (not asylum seekers which are a completely different class of persons) are not being charged in respect of their entry to Canada.

Under Article 31 of the 1951 Convention on Refugees Canada has undertaken to not prosecute refugee claimants for illegal entry into Canada including any issues of false documents or fraud relating to that entry.

Canada has enacted that exemption into our domestic law as required by the Convention in various iterations of our immigration legislation over the years. Currently that exemption is contained at s. 133 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

So no charges because the law exempts refugees recognizing that refugees who are fleeing persecution are different from other migrants.

Comment: No. you are wrong. The legislation was passed in 1961 to assist Alberta. The Alberta price of oil was $3.00 while the Saudis delivered up the new St Lawrence Seaway to Chicago for $1.70, occasionally $1.50. The Americans lost interest in Alberta oil. (Sound familiar?) 

Two new pipelines were built to supply Canada as far east as Toronto and Montreal. One carried Alberta natural gas (north of Lake Superior) and the other (Enbridge, south of Lake Superior) carries crude oil. All of Canada west of the Ottawa river which includes Ontario were obligated to use Alberta petroleum.

The Arab oil cartel artificially inflated the price of crude in the mid 70s, eventually to $30 from $3, and a world recession ensued. The substitute for the NOP, the new NEP, was intended to partially shield Canadians from the artificially inflated Arab cartel price.  Alberta felt it was it's right to have the cartel equivalent from Canadians, and so today Ontario buys oil on the world market (St Lawrence Seaway).

Comment: Thank you for clarifying for others. One thing readers should know is that journalists frequently report on new research. They write a story about the research. In such stories, they link out to the original study where readers can scrutinize methods, findings, and interpretations at a higher level. That link is usually located very early in the article, so that serious readers can jump right there and read the research for themselves, often skipping past a journalist's overview entirely. Readers should also know that primary research articles generally are not published in daily newspapers. They are more often published in academic journals or become part of an institutional report. In this case, it's a Dept. of Labor report.

Comment: You are oversimplifying things. It isn't a matter of charity, just being on the wrong side.

Over the next 80 years that terrible mistake resulted in:

- the deaths of tens of millions of Russians at the hand of their government,
- the establishment of a KGB police state which set the stage for the current autocratic government,
- the imprisonment or exile of countless dissidents,
- a Cold War which cost the planet far too much,
- a brain drain which saw many of Russia's best minds leave,
- an economic stunting which still affects Russia to this day
- and more.

Comment: Cliff, I'm just a layman trying to understand the science, and happy to change my mind on anything as new evidence presents itself.  I have zero credentials, but then the problem with that argument is that there are scientists with impeccable credentials on both sides of the climate debate.  My point on weather models is simply that you have the opportunity to test predictions on a frequent basis.  I'd think that would help to improve those models over time.  

On uncertainty in the models, it would be interesting to see the magnitude of the potential error of other variables vs. the magnitude of the effect we're attributing to CO2.  Not sure if Patrick Frank is close or way off on that one.

The radiative effects of CO2 are actually growing logarithmically rather than exponentially, aren't they?  i.e., theoretically you get the same warming effect (~1.2 deg C) from a doubling of the concentration, whether that's from 300 to 600ppm or 600 to 1200ppm.

Comment: As I said in a previous post, I've served on a few hiring committees over the years. Staffing decisions are among the most difficult that an organization has to make. In retrospect, the track record for the decisions in which I participated was mixed, but where we failed I think the main attribute we discounted was experience. I can't speak to the issue of lack of Canadian experience per se, but I suspect that in a market featuring labour surpluses it's mainly used as a deselection criterion. As it turns out, studies have shown that human beings aren't particularly adept at making objective hiring decisions and I can attest to that. Skills testing is considered a more accurate assessment mechanism than evaluating resumes and/or conducting interviews, but where "intangible" qualities like character and leadership skills are important I believe it's important to consider verifiable experience although I understand this could well put new immigrants at an unfair disadvantage.

Comment: Excellent suggestions Brooks, but perhaps far too logical to make it into the hearts and minds of the people who actually have the power to do something about it!

As to your statement: "resulted in the collection of more than 7,000 firearms for Britain’s defense against potential invasion by Germany (Britain had virtually disarmed itself with a series of gun-control laws enacted between World War I and World War II)" - they may well have enacted such legislation, but the real reason the UK needed as many weapons as it could lay its hands on at that time was due to the simple fact that virtually all its existing weapons had been left behind on the beaches of Dunkirk, during the mad rush to escape France.

It was this that led to the British Home Guard training with broomsticks and pitchforks in 1940, and also what led to the development of the Sten gun, a cheap, easy to mass-produce sub-machine gun with a distinctive side magazine.

Comment: Good essay . But using the most simplistic supply-and-demand model for labour, there wil always be a market-clearing wage that will provide work for those who want it. So today, as always, we have employment. But the key is the market-clearing wage. We observe two things:

1. A long-run increased income disparity, driven mostly by a long-run increase in the disparity in factors explaining various wage rates;

2.  A long-run decrease in the wage/nominal-GDP ratio. I.e., the wage bill as a percentage of the value of production is declining.

Both of these phenomena are interrelated, but the reality of machines replacing humans will worsen these trends. -- David Murrell, Economics, UNB t Fredericton

Comment: Alaska Has a Two-Fold Problem, but primarily a spending problem.

Alaska has approximately 10% of the population of WA state.

WA state, with no income tax and a sales tax spends approximately $5,598 per person. Alaska with no income tax and no statewide sales tax spends approximately $18,196 per person.

Multiply Washington States $5,598 spending per person x 3.25 and you arrive at AK spending per person of $18,196. Granted it is more expensive to live and do business in AK than WA but is it three times more expensive?

Between 2014 and 2015 Alaska’s spending increased from 2.4 billion to 11.4 billion, a $9 billion or 17.22 percent increase. Was there a corresponding increase in revenue into the state from businesses and or federal largess? Or did we just deficit spend?

Is it really 3 times more expensive than WA state to operate Alaska’s state government? If so, why?

Let’s start with a spending cap before we start with an income or statewide sales tax.

While meaningful transformation is bound to be a gradual process, given the institutional exclusion that has to be dismantled at every level, 23 years has seen an entire generation of athletes lose opportunities that COULD have had a different outcome. Feeder leagues at school and club level, particularly in historically disadvantaged areas, are still grossly mismanaged or even non-existent. There is to be collaboration between the departments of sport, education & social development to allocate far more attention to improving facilities & administration at development stages. We can't only focus on rugby, cricket & soccer. We can't only focus on men & boys. We can't continue to allow poor planning, misuse of funds & exploitation (failed expensive Commonwealth Games bid, lavish entourages to Mayweather fight, etc.) because while transformation MUST happen, we could have done & could be doing so much better.

Comment: All my working life I never had a pension plan.  I started work around the time we were told we could do better if we manage our own pensions using RRSPs and personal savings.   I took that seriously and saved every year, and saved alot.  I also took risks by investing.   RRSPs are not enough - I needed to supplement those funds with personal taxable investments.  I will not be relying on government benefits because I did this.  

I wonder if it was worth it.  I could have found a job with a defined benefit pension and avoided all the work and worry of building my own pension.   

Increasing taxes on capital gains and dividend income is punishing me for being responsible.  And, by the way, I am not part of the 1% - I am middle class which is where I wanted to be.

Comment: No, he's not kidding.   ...and Yes, tenant gets a 3-day notice, plus a late charge assessed on the 2nd.  
Tenant also receives notice that tenant will be held responsible for Landlord's eviction and court cost from that date forward.  Landlords usually expect all hell to break loose at that point, so landlords take precaution by putting law enforcement on notice, in case of any property damage.  Law officer serves tenant with "Summons and Complaint" after day 3, which tells the Tenant when his court date is--but by that time, it's too late. Landlord will ask court for Judgement of possession, plus financial costs.  ...Court drafts a Writ of Restitution (ordering removal of tenants belongings), ...Sheriff shows up while Landlord puts Tenants' stuff on the curb and changes the locks.  It all happens faster than you might think!

Comment: "Governments are awash in money. The economy is great, unemployment is low, people are moving here..."

All true except the awash in money.  Some may be, but let's step into the real world and visit a not-quite suburb of Denver, namely Elbert County.

Totally Repub dominated, to the point that I haven't seen a Dem win a single election in almost 20 years.  Virtually every tax increase ballot issue is defeated also, even those that are needed.  
County books are open, just no money there since the taxes are so low.  It's to the ridiculous point of applying paper thin asphalt patches on the worst sections of highly travelled roads instead of giving them the maintenance they need - and that's on top of 10 years of chip seal to patch potholes and cracks.

Not all are awash in money, and I'd bet that many semi-rural & rural counties are in the same boat.  I support Tabor, but also support tax increases when truly justified instead of just having the knee jerk reaction of "heck no!".

Comment: Groucho,

I think you're missing the challenge that woman's observation exposes: a public perception that we must overcome if we are to make them part of our fellowship. Many times I have seen someone who disagreed on a doctrinal issue become part of the church because they were first welcomed into the fellowship and as they became integrated into the social network of the church they were drawn closer to God in ways that whittled-away at their opposition until it disappeared. If we're socially repulsive, it doesn't matter how correct we are on doctrine because we'll just be driving people away from God. What is there about your relationships with others, about the social programs and ministries and fellowship of your church that will draw people to God with greater power than what is driving them away?

Comment: I actually think that Burns got the  meaning of Vietnam wrong conceptually. One thing that happened during the war is that everyone had to decide what to do about a common issue. Yes people did different things. But every young American of that era - well all men for sure - have an answer to the question "what did you do during the Vietnam war?" As far as I can tell in the U.S. today there is no issue that everyone must figure out a way to personally respond to. There is no shared trauma. Indeed almost no shared anything. And that means people only talk to people who see the world like they do. Vietnam was different. However you responded to being drafted, you were linked to others who might responded differently. Right or wrong it was everyone's war. As I said before: There is no everyone's anything in the U.S. today.

Fact is, America, the Constitution itself is an example of social engineering, an attempt to apply human reason to problems of governance and power that, before the Constitution were subject only to divine solutions.
